briefOverview: The revelation instructs church leaders and members on how to pursue the redemption of Zion after persecution, coupling promises of divine help with conditions of obedience.
summary: The Lord explains that the Saints’ scattering in Zion serves both to fill the measure of their enemies’ iniquity and to chasten His people for partial disobedience, yet He decrees that if they now hearken, they will begin to prevail. They are called to be a light and “saviors of men,” warned against losing their savor, and promised eventual restoration to their inheritances after tribulation, contingent on purity and obedience. The redemption of Zion will come by power, with a leader raised up “like as Moses,” and God promises both His angels and His presence as they move toward the “goodly land.” Joseph Smith is identified with the servant in a prior parable, and he is to rally the strength of the Church, while the Saints send funds and wise men to purchase lands and prepare. The revelation authorizes strong measures against enemies, exhorts disciples to be willing to lay down their lives for Christ, and assigns specific leaders (Sidney Rigdon, Parley P. Pratt, Lyman Wight, Hyrum Smith, Frederick G. Williams, Orson Hyde, Orson Pratt) to recruit companies—ideally 500, but at least 100—toward the redemption effort. It closes by affirming that victory comes through diligence, faithfulness, and prayers of faith.
externalContext: In late 1833, Latter-day Saints were expelled from Jackson County, Missouri—identified by them as the land of Zion—amid escalating tensions with local residents. In early 1834, church leaders in Kirtland, Ohio, organized efforts to aid displaced members and seek redress; this culminated in the expedition later known as Zion’s Camp, aimed at assisting the Missouri Saints and reclaiming lands. Purchasing land for settlements had been an ongoing strategy, even amid legal disputes and petitions to authorities. The leaders named in this chapter were prominent early figures tasked with recruitment, preaching, and logistical preparation for the relief expedition.
externalReferences: The identification of Joseph Smith as the servant refers back to the parable of the nobleman and the olive-trees (Doctrine and Covenants 101:44–62), in which a servant rallies the “strength of my house” to redeem the Lord’s vineyard. The language of being led “like as Moses,” with a “stretched-out arm,” echoes the Exodus deliverance (e.g., Exodus 6:6), and the promise that an angel will go before them resonates with Exodus 23:20. The imagery of being a light and the warning about salt losing its savor reflect Jesus’ teaching in the Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5:13–14). The call to be willing to lay down one’s life parallels Jesus’ sayings on losing life for His sake (Matthew 10:39; cf. Mark 8:35; John 15:13).
practicalQuestions: Where might I need to respond promptly to divine correction so promised blessings can unfold?
How can I actively be a light and a “savior of men” without losing spiritual integrity or influence?
What sacrifices—time, resources, even safety—am I prepared to offer for covenant commitments?
How do I balance urgent action with patient trust in God’s timing and conditions for success?
How should I interpret and apply the chapter’s strong language about cursing and avenging enemies in a Christlike way today?
uncertainAreas: How to interpret the scope and manner of “cursing” and “avenging” enemies in vv. 24–26; whether the Moses-like leader in vv. 15–18 is strictly Joseph Smith (v. 21 identifies him with the servant from D&C 101, but the relationship between these figures can be read variously); and how literally or symbolically to apply the martial language to later contexts.
